editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO MY REVEREND BRETHREN, THE PASTOVRS OF Parochiall Congregations in the Church of England.
div.p:
REuerend Brethren, euer Å¿ince my firÅ¿t entring into a PaÅ¿torall charge, I haue applied mine endeauours, by CatechiÅ¿ing to inÅ¿truct the ignorant. And becauÅ¿e I would not be irregular, my Theame hath alwaies been the Å¿hort CatechiÅ¿me, Å¿et forth in the Booke of Common Prayer, a CatechiÅ¿me indeede, Å¿olely appointed to bee firÅ¿t taught; but to the great detriment of our Church either wholly neglected, any other being preferred, or barely taught without any further explanation, or elÅ¿e for outward formality onely in Lent Å¿et vpon the Table, as a diÅ¿h appropriated to that FaÅ¿t. My Å¿tudy hath been
firÅ¿t to mend this fault for my owne particular, and therefore I haue diuers yeares labored conÅ¿tantly throughout the yeare, by this kind of teaching to forme in my hearers Å¿ome diÅ¿tinct knowledge of our ChriÅ¿tian Principles: and hauing at length come to my intended period, I digeÅ¿ted the pith of all my Collections and Meditations into this Booke, herein imitating
Æ²rÅ¿inus vpon Melanctons Å¿hort CatechiÅ¿me, Å¿o vÅ¿efull to young Students in Theologie, and to other Å¿tudious perÅ¿ons. The labour thus ended, being conÅ¿cious to my Å¿elf of mine own weaknes, I Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed it three or foure yeares, till that being animated by Å¿ome of you (my Brethren) who had either Å¿eene or heard hereof, I haue aduentured to bring it into publike view. The worke I confeÅ¿Å¿e is ordinary and worthles; but for forme it is alone, and Å¿o may craue entertainement. Heere are collected into one all fundamentall points, of the true ChriÅ¿tian Religion, Å¿parÅ¿edlie handled in diuers learned Bookes, and applied to the Å¿hort EngliÅ¿h CatechiÅ¿me. It is a CatechiÅ¿me and a Comentarie, the one for Children, Å¿hort, and fitted to their capacity, the other for men, leading to a larger mappe of ChriÅ¿tian Principles, and fitted for
the edification of all. To haue written a large new CatechiÅ¿me without an old text, had bin Å¿uperfluous amongÅ¿t Å¿o many already abroad, but to write for the illuÅ¿trating of the Text, to which we EngliÅ¿h muÅ¿t all hold vs, is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary. In publiÅ¿hing this, I take not vpon me to preÅ¿cribe a forme vnto any, my Å¿elfe being the leaÅ¿t amongÅ¿t thouÅ¿ands, but I whet on all, what I can, to an vniforme proceeding by our common grounds. We haue all one God, one ChriÅ¿t, one BaptiÅ¿me, one GoÅ¿pell, and one forme of Articles of Religion, to which wee Å¿ubÅ¿cribe; why then Å¿hould we not all conÅ¿ent in one CatechiÅ¿me? Our Mother the Church of England, hath firÅ¿t commaunded this one CatechiÅ¿me, vpon which is my Commentary. If therefore my inward wiÅ¿hes may breake foorth into open requeÅ¿t, I would craue that it might pleaÅ¿e the right Reuerend Fathers of our Church, more Å¿trictly to preÅ¿Å¿e the teaching of our common CatechiÅ¿me in their Å¿euerall IuriÅ¿dictions: and you my Brethren, who doe already teach it in your Å¿euerall PariÅ¿hes, to labour in it with all diligence, and to bring it in, and commend it to the priuate exerciÅ¿e of your people in their families, amongÅ¿t whom it
hath hitherto been much neglected. And I beÅ¿eech you all fauourably to accept this my preÅ¿ent act, and where I haue faulted, correct me; where I haue failed, Å¿upply me; where I haue done rightly, ioyne with me. If this may be any thing, though but goats hayre, towards the Lords Sanctuary, I Å¿hall be glad, and giue God the glory. Our great Shepheard, the Lord IeÅ¿us, who hath laid downe his life for his Å¿heepe, make this and all the endeauours of his Seruants, fruitfull paÅ¿tures for the comfort of his flocke, and for the praiÅ¿e of his holy and glorious name. Amen.

closer.signed: Your fellow-Seruant in the worke of the MiniÅ¿tery. IOHN MAYER.

list.item: QueÅ¿tion. WHom doe the Articles of your faith concerne?
AnÅ¿w. The firÅ¿t part of them concernes God: the Å¿econd, the Church of God. 21

AnÅ¿w. Man onely had Å¿inned, it was moÅ¿t agreeable to the IuÅ¿tice of God; to receiue the paiment of the debt of Å¿inne, in the Å¿ame nature of Å¿inne, which committed it. 36

QueÅ¿t. Are not the Apocrypha Bookes part of the word of God?

AnÅ¿w. It is proued by their antiquity, Å¿ome of them being before all other bokes, Å¿undry times oppugned and Å¿ought to be burnt vp by perÅ¿ecutors, and yet wonderfully preÅ¿erued, and by miracles from Heauen confirmed, which Å¿hewes that they came from heauen, and are not of mans inuention. 547

div.p: WHAT is your name?

This Primer QueÅ¿tion may bee called the way to the Church dore: it leadeth to the mention of BaptiÅ¿me, which is the gate of ChriÅ¿tianity. It is prefixed before our CatechiÅ¿me, as an Introduction, or familiar entrance, framed by queÅ¿tion and anÅ¿wer, for the inÅ¿truction of the Å¿impler: and therefore is not idle and vnfitting, as Å¿ome would haue it, but very agreeable to the matter intended. InaÅ¿much, as a ChriÅ¿tian mans name doth not onely diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h him from other men of different names; but alÅ¿o Å¿erueth for a remembrance, whereby the grace of God Å¿hould bee Å¿tirred vp in him. Thus the people had names of old: Adam, Å¿ignifying
red earth; Euah, a mother: Abram, an high father: IÅ¿aac, laughing: Iacob, Å¿upplanting: and the Lord himÅ¿elfe hath a name preÅ¿cribed, IeÅ¿us, a Sauiour, &c. Neither were theÅ¿e names giuen by chance, but Almighty God himÅ¿elfe being the firÅ¿t guide hereunto, and many times appoynting the name, then holy men followed; and generally, all the world in former ages, gaue names of Å¿peciall Å¿ignification. Pharaohs daughter called the Hebrew childe drawn out of the riuer, MoÅ¿es, Drawne-out. IoÅ¿eph was proclaimed by Pharaoh the King, Abres, Father; when, as a Father hee prouided for the Countrey, &c. A more eÅ¿peciall dayly monitory may this bee to vs, for that our name doth remember vnto vs our ChriÅ¿tian ProfeÅ¿sion, that wee may walke worthy of the Å¿ame. QueÅ¿t. Whether may a man change his name or not?
QueÅ¿t. Who gaue you this name?
AnÅ¿w. My God-fathers, and Godmothers, in my BaptiÅ¿me, wherein I was made a member of ChriÅ¿t, a childe of God, and Inheritor of the Kingdome of Heauen.

Explan. In this anÅ¿were I obÅ¿erue three things. FirÅ¿t, the time of the name giuing. viz. In BaptiÅ¿me. For this is both anÅ¿werable to the practiÅ¿e of the Church of God in all ages, Å¿ince there was a Sacrament of BaptiÅ¿me, or any other in the roome therof, & Å¿tandeth with very good reaÅ¿on. As for the cuÅ¿tome of the Church; Abraham, at the firÅ¿t inÅ¿titution of the CircumciÅ¿ion, is Å¿aid, to haue circumciÅ¿ed his Å¿onne the eight day, and to haue called his name IÅ¿aac,
Gen. 21âª and this cuÅ¿tome held as long as circumciÅ¿ion, as may bee Å¿eene in Iohn BaptiÅ¿t: When they came to circumciÅ¿e the babe,

Exod. 2.22. 4.25. was named before his circumciÅ¿ion, for he was afterwards circumciÅ¿ed, when the Lord met MoÅ¿es in the Inne, and would haue Å¿laine him: Rachel, Iaacobs wife, Gen. 35.18. immediately after her trauell, named her child Benoni, and during the time of the IÅ¿raelites being in the wilderneÅ¿Å¿e, for forty yeeres, JoÅ¿. 5.2. they were without circumciÅ¿ion, but it is not likely they were without names. Sol. This laÅ¿t was an extraordinary time, neceÅ¿Å¿itie made them diÅ¿penÅ¿e with law; for that act of Rachels, it onely Å¿hewes her deÅ¿ire, for the child was afterwards called Beniamin, viz. at the circumciÅ¿ion. LaÅ¿tly, for the firÅ¿t, no maruell though the cuÅ¿tome of the Church were broken, Å¿eeing that Gods ordinance was alÅ¿o neglected, for feare of impatient Zipporah. SecoÌdly, what fitter time can be to impoÅ¿e names, then when we begin to bee? we are firÅ¿t borne, and then haue the common name of man,
then we are borne againe, and haue the Å¿peciall names of ChriÅ¿tians. The Å¿econd thing in the anÅ¿wer; the perÅ¿ons that giue the name, Godfathers and Godmothers. True it is, that Parents were alwayes wont to propound the name. IoÅ¿eph directed by the Angell told what the name of JeÅ¿us Å¿hould be: Zachary, of his Å¿onne Iohn: and ordinarily, Abraham, MoÅ¿es, IoÅ¿eph in Aegypt (alÅ¿o Hannah named Samuel; & Rachel, IoÅ¿eph. But the Godfathers, following the direction of the parents, haue vÅ¿ed a long time to propound the name in publique: when Iohn was to be circumciÅ¿ed, it is Å¿aid, They call d his name, &c. But his parents had the greateÅ¿t Å¿troke in determining the name.Obiections againÅ¿t Godfathers anÅ¿wered One, writing againÅ¿t our cuÅ¿tome herein, alledgeth the Councell of Nice, Can. 30. Let no faithfull man name his children by heathen names; and that of Baronius. My Parents called me Tarr â¢ chus, and out of DionyÅ¿ius, that the PrieÅ¿t was wont to aske the name at the Church doore, and hence endeauoureth to proue, that Parents, and not Godfathers, are to name their children, neither at the time of baptiÅ¿me, but before, for which he further addeth, that they, which were Adulti, were wont to come before their baptiÅ¿me, and put their old names in the RegiÅ¿ter. Vnto which I anÅ¿were. FirÅ¿t, that of the Councell of Nice, is a meere forgery, there being but twenty Canons in all, or two and twenty at the moÅ¿t. Secondly, admit it to be true, and that which followeth; it is no more then we confeÅ¿Å¿e, that Parents haue, or ought to haue, the chiefeÅ¿t Å¿troke in the names of their owne children. LaÅ¿tly, for the Adulti holding their own names, it might be through conniuency, in Å¿ome particular Church, at Å¿ome time onely. For it is moÅ¿t euident, that Godfathers were vÅ¿ed amongÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tians, euen in the Primitiue Church. Higinus, BiÅ¿hop of Rome, and Martyr, Å¿peakes of them in his fift Decretall, who was but 140. yeeres after ChriÅ¿ts incarnation, and the beÅ¿t reformed Churches doe allow of them. ReaÅ¿ons why Godfathers are vÅ¿ed. 1. It is not againÅ¿t the Scriptures. 2. It is moÅ¿t ancient. 3. It proceeds from loue, of the parents procuring them, of them vndertaking. 4. It is to the benefit of the Infant, if

3. The third thing in the anÅ¿wer is, the addition: Wherein I was made a member of ChriÅ¿t, &c. Which is not Å¿o to be vnderÅ¿tood, as though the outward waÅ¿hing of water, did make the baptized partaker of theÅ¿e Å¿o excellent benefits: for it is true of the Sacraments of the new TeÅ¿tament, which was Å¿ayd of them of the old: It is impoÅ¿sible,

Gal. 15. That the Å¿ame may be Å¿aid of BaptiÅ¿me, Å¿ee in the PhariÅ¿ies comming to Iohn his BaptiÅ¿me: O generation of Æ²ipers (Å¿aith hee, Luk. 3.7. who hath forewarned you to flie from the wrath to come? Where hee Å¿heweth, baptiÅ¿me to be a meanes of eÅ¿caping Gods wrath, after an implicite manner; but withall, requires vertue, which being away, baptiÅ¿me auaileth not. And our Lord hauing commended baptiÅ¿me to all, excepteth yet, Å¿aying; He that belieueth not Å¿hall be damned. The caÅ¿e herein is diuers, Mark. 16.16. FirÅ¿t, in thoÅ¿e that are of ripe yeeres and vnderÅ¿tanding: there is required of them a due diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of repentance, and faith, actually performed by, and in themÅ¿elues. But in Infants it is enough that they pertaine to the Couenant, being born â¢ in the boÅ¿ome of the Church, and preÅ¿ented to the participation of gracious adoption by vertue of the Faith of their Parents.

The right vnderÅ¿tanding then of this is, that in our baptiÅ¿me, we are Å¿acramentally, or inÅ¿trumentally, made the children of God; and really, and truly, when we are together baptized with the Holy GhoÅ¿t; if thou beleeue, and be baptized, thou art made Inheritor of the Kingdome of Heauen, and this is aÅ¿cribed vnto baptiÅ¿me. Wherefore let no man miÅ¿take this matter, thinking himÅ¿elfe Å¿afe, when he is baptized, for he may, nay, infinite numbers doe, notwithÅ¿tanding periÅ¿h.
BaptiÅ¿me confers not Grace, Ex opere operato, as the Church of Rome teacheth; but euer, in men of yeares as they were found in grace, they were thought fit to be baptized. Read of the Eunuch, of Cornelius and his company, of the conuerts amongÅ¿t the Iewes at Peters preaching.Act. 8 &c. 10 chap. 2. Now then conÅ¿ider, whether this be thy caÅ¿e or no? Art thou indued with grace? Art thou baptized with the Holy GhoÅ¿t? Art thou baptized into ChriÅ¿t? BeleeueÅ¿t thou with all thy heart? repenteÅ¿t thou with a true and due compunction? If it be thus, thou haÅ¿t put on ChriÅ¿t, thou art buried with him by baptiÅ¿me, Rom. 6.2. into his death, that like as Christ was raiÅ¿ed from the dead, Å¿o alÅ¿o thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t walke in newnes of life. St. Paul in his Å¿alutations Å¿tyleth the whole viÅ¿ible Churches, to whom hee writes by the title of Saints, and yet it is likely that by his extraordinary diÅ¿cerning Å¿pirit, he could haue differenced the goats of his flocke from the Å¿heepe. How much more ought we, with our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Mother the Church of England, at all chaÅ¿tenings, preÅ¿ume that Å¿acramentall grace, doth like a Å¿oule enquicken the body of the outward element, and receiue theÅ¿e for our true fellow-members of ChriÅ¿t,
who haue beene made partakers of the Å¿ame labor of regeneration?
QueÅ¿t. What did thy Godfathers and Godmothers then for thee?

AnÅ¿w. They did promiÅ¿e and vow three things in my name, firÅ¿t, that I Å¿hould forÅ¿ake the diuel, and all his workes, the pompes and vanities of this wicked world, with all the Å¿infull luÅ¿ts of the fleÅ¿h. Explan. In this anÅ¿were obÅ¿erue foure points, which are further to be opened. FirÅ¿t, wherefore this promiÅ¿e is made of forÅ¿aking the diuell, &c. For the reÅ¿olution of which,Mans foure-fold eÅ¿tate. 1 of Inocency. Gen 1 27. EccleÅ¿. 7.1. it is to be vnderÅ¿tood, that our naturall eÅ¿tate is carnall, and Å¿enÅ¿uall, yea a very Å¿ubiection vnto Satan. True it is, that man by his firÅ¿t creation was holy and righteous, witneÅ¿Å¿e the Spirit himÅ¿elfe; Å¿aying thus. God made man in his owne Image, in the Jmage of God created he him. And God made man righteous, and this eÅ¿tate of holineÅ¿Å¿e was accompanied with exquiÅ¿ite, and almoÅ¿t Diuine knowledge: for proofe wherof, the creatures were brought vnto him to be named, and as he named them, Å¿o they were called: now his names did Å¿o fit the creatures, expreÅ¿Å¿ing partly their Å¿euerall natures, that if a moÅ¿t cunning PhiloÅ¿opher had Å¿tudied all his life, he could not haue done the like. BeÅ¿ides this, he being caÅ¿t into a deepe Å¿leepe, when the woman was taken out of his Å¿ide, did rightly diuine how neere Å¿hee was vnto him, Å¿aying: This is fleÅ¿h of my fleÅ¿h, and bone of my bone &c. Againe, Gen. 2.23. vnto his knowledge was added a Å¿ound eÅ¿tate of body, (from all diÅ¿eaÅ¿es,) as death it Å¿elfe came in by Å¿inne: Rom 5.18. hee could labour without wearines: for the Å¿weat of the brow comes in after the tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ioÌ. De OpiÅ¿ â¢â¢ . lÃ´is cap. 17. 2 Of corruption. Rom. 3.23. Now man is fallen from this eÅ¿tate, Å¿inne proceeding from one Adam hath ouerÅ¿pread all men. All haue Å¿inned and are depriued of the glory of God. There is in vs all, Å¿o Å¿oone as we are, a want of all grace and goodnes, a proneneÅ¿Å¿e vnto euill, and vntowardnes to doe that, which is pleaÅ¿ing to the Lord, as both St. Paul Å¿etteth forth in himÅ¿elfe, Å¿aying; Rom. 7.15. Of grace. if the heart be purified by faith; if hee faithfully beleeue all the Articles of the ChriÅ¿tian faith, and be Å¿anctified to obedience of life, if hee alwayes walke in the wayes of Gods commandements; faith giuing him intereÅ¿t in this eÅ¿tate, and obedience certifying; that hee is truely intereÅ¿Å¿ed heerein, according to that of the ApoÅ¿tle: Shew me thy faith by thy workes.
Jam. 2.18. Eph. 2.2. Rom. 6. Ioh. 8.34. 1 Joh. 3. Heb. 2 15. Luc. 1.7.4. Heb. 11.6. 2. Cor. 8. And as our condition vnder Å¿inne is moÅ¿t terrible; Å¿o is this vnder grace moÅ¿t comfortable. Then wee were dead in Å¿innes and treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es: now wee are dead vnto Å¿inne, and aliue vnto God in righteouÅ¿nes: then wee were Å¿eruants, yea bondÅ¿laues; now wee are Å¿et at liberty, yea made Å¿onnes of God: then wee were euery day in feare; now we Å¿erue the Lord all our life time without feare: then our beÅ¿t workes did diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e God; now, though wee faile in many things, wee are accepted
according to that we haue, Eph. 2. and not according to that wee haue not: then we were without God in the world to protect vs; now wee are made neere, Rom. 6.23. yea of the houÅ¿hold of God: to conclude, wee were at the day of payment to receiue for our wages, death, now wee Å¿hall not taÅ¿t of that death, but haue the guift of our God, which is eternall life. And heere is the laÅ¿t end; the fourth eÅ¿tate of man indued with grace, which Å¿hall be without end,4. Of glory. the firÅ¿t fruits of this are had heere, halfe the harueÅ¿t followes at euery mans particular death, the Å¿oule being placed in ParadiÅ¿e, and all is perfected at the day of Iudgement, when both Å¿oule and body inioy the kingdome of God the Father.

Secondly, we are further to conÅ¿ider, whether we be able and haue of our Å¿elues power to forÅ¿ake the diuell, &c. and if not, whence wee are to Å¿eeke for this. Eph. 2.2. Of free will. The words indeed Å¿eeme to intimate Å¿uch ability, but they haue no Å¿uch meaning: for we are dead in Å¿innes and treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es; that is, haue as little ability to doe any act of grace, as a dead man hath to moue himÅ¿elfe, or to doe any thing, that belongs vnto the liuing. Wee are not Å¿ufficient of our Å¿elues to thinke a good thought, as of our Å¿elues: It is not in him that willeth, 2. Cor 3.5. Rom. 9.16. or in him that runneth, but in God that Å¿heweth mercy. that by the grace of the Lord, we are heerein holpen againÅ¿t Å¿inne, becauÅ¿e that by this is opened vnto vs, what wee ought to doe, and what to Å¿hunne, and that it doth not effect this in vs, that we chuÅ¿e, and are able to doe what wee are commanded, let him be an anathema: and not long after in another councell: WhoÅ¿oeuer Å¿hall Å¿ay, Conc: ArauÅ¿: can. 3.
that at mans calling vpon God, his grace is beÅ¿towed, and that grace it Å¿elfe doth not worke this in vs, that wee call vpon him, hee Å¿peakes againÅ¿t that of the Prophet EÅ¿ay, I was found of them that Å¿ought mee not, and was manifeÅ¿ted to thoÅ¿e that asked not after me: Nay, the fathers in this Councell goe further, Can. 4. and denie

Rom. 10.14 Wee are therefore to Å¿eeke for this at the hands of God, wee muÅ¿t reade, heare, and learne, that wee may bee able to Å¿ee. FirÅ¿t, wee muÅ¿t learne the grownds of the ChriÅ¿tian religion, the Lords prayer, Creed, and ten Commandements, and then diligently heare Sermons; for how Å¿hall wee call vpon him, of whom wee haue not heard, and how Å¿hall wee heare without a Preacher? Fourthly let vs take a briefe view, what be thoÅ¿e abhominations which a ChriÅ¿tian at his firÅ¿t oath of allegeance to God, is to abiure Å¿olemnly. They are the Diuell and his workes, the pompes and vanities of this wicked world.

But to returne to the Å¿ubiect matter whereupon this diÅ¿clayming and forÅ¿aking is to be employed, it is a troupe of encompaÅ¿Å¿ing and beÅ¿ieging enemies all too neere vs, partly round about vs, and partly within vs. The Diuell, an inuiÅ¿ible foe, moÅ¿t powerfull by his own Å¿ubtilty and malice, he Å¿etteth vpon vs by Å¿uggeÅ¿tions to draw vs to his works. The world a more viÅ¿ible foe, moÅ¿t inÅ¿naring by entiÅ¿ements and blandiÅ¿hments, that dazleth our eyes with the luÅ¿ter of glittering pompes, & fading vanities. Our putting on gorgeous apparrell makes vs eaÅ¿ily forget our putting on ChriÅ¿t, & our loging to be cloathed with immortallity: Å¿umptuous buildings make vs too Å¿oone forget the houÅ¿e Not made with hands which we haue in the heauens. 2, Cor. 5.2. Feathers, fans, foretops, paintings, &c. Do Å¿o Å¿ophiÅ¿ticate our bodies, & entoxicate our Å¿oules, as if we preferred theÅ¿e enÅ¿ignes of vanitie, & diÅ¿guiÅ¿es of mortall bodies, before the hoped beauty and Å¿plendor of glorified bodies.

Ob. It Å¿eemeth then that all outward pompe and Å¿ecular glory is renounced in our ChriÅ¿tendome. What then Å¿hall become of Kings Courts, Royall Å¿hewes, triumphs, &c. MuÅ¿t theÅ¿e be ranged amongÅ¿t the forbidden vanities?

Sol. Verely no. As there are in all well-gouernd ChriÅ¿tian
common-wealths, diÅ¿tinctions of habits, ornaments, and buildings, to put a difference betweene Å¿euerall degrees of Å¿ubiects, Å¿o much more is it fit that there Å¿hould be a maieÅ¿tique Å¿plendor whereby the Prince and his Court may be conÅ¿picuous aboue others. In domibus Regum Å¿unt, qui mollibus indumentis veÅ¿tiuntur. It is the brainÅ¿ick humor of Å¿ome AnabaptiÅ¿ts to lay all the world leuell. Nor is it maruell that they, who defie all Kings, as limbes of the wicked world, and Å¿courges of the diÅ¿ciples, Å¿hould deny all roabes of ornament, exceeding the skirts of a weauers or millers iacket. Our vow in BaptiÅ¿me renownceth not ciuil pompes befitting particular callings or occaÅ¿ions, but the exceÅ¿Å¿e of them, they being too much poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by them, tranÅ¿ported with them, or addicted to them. The world, the fleÅ¿h, and the Diuell.The third foe is moÅ¿t Å¿enÅ¿ible and inÅ¿eperable, becauÅ¿e neereÅ¿t vs, moÅ¿t powerfull in perÅ¿wading and conquering vs, becauÅ¿e it dealeth with vs, not as a Å¿tranger, but a deare part of our Å¿elues. This weaker part of vs is the Å¿tronger by entiÅ¿ements, Å¿o that we often againe embrace it and beg â¢ t compleate Å¿inne vpon it, though wee haue in our baptiÅ¿me pronounced a finall diuorce againÅ¿t it. Looke to thy Å¿elfe therefore thou baptized ChriÅ¿tian, put on thy Å¿pirituall armour of proofe, Ã´ thou champion of God, proÅ¿ecute thy defiance againÅ¿t the Diuell, the world, and the fleÅ¿h, for that they are all Gods enemies, and all enemies to thine owne Å¿oule. FirÅ¿t, that they be Gods enemies, is plaine; the Diuell aduanceth himÅ¿elfe as a God in this world,2. Cor. 4.4. Eph. 2.2. for which hee is called the God of
this world, 2 Cor. 4 4. Eph. 2.2. and a Prince that ruleth in the ayre. Now hee that Å¿hall take vpon himÅ¿elfe to bee a King, is the true Kings moÅ¿t deadly and greateÅ¿t enemy: Å¿o is the diuell. The world conÅ¿idered,1. Joh. 2 15. not naturally, as it Å¿ignifieth the frame of heauen and earth, or things neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the the maintenance of this corporall life: but morally as Å¿ignifying vnlawfull or immoderate pleaÅ¿ures, or cares abÅ¿tracting or entiÅ¿ing from God; in this reÅ¿pect the world is Å¿uch an enemy vnto God, as that the friends of the world are pronounced Gods enemies, and hee that Å¿erues the world cannot but hate God. Gal 5.17. LaÅ¿tly, the fleÅ¿h is Å¿aid to fight againÅ¿t the Spirit of God. Moreouer, they be alÅ¿o thine enemies: The diuell as a Lyon,1 Pet. 5.7. goeth about Å¿eeking whom hee may deuoure: Wee muÅ¿t prepare euery day to fight againÅ¿t him: Eph. 6.12. for wee are not to fight only againÅ¿t fleÅ¿h and bloud; but againÅ¿t principalities and Å¿pirituall powers in heauenly places: Math. 13 22. the world as briers and thornes doth choke the Å¿eed of Gods word in our hearts, and make vs vnprofitable hearers:1. Tim. 6.9. it is as a pit of water cloÅ¿ely made to drown thy Å¿oule in perdition: Rom. 7. and the fleÅ¿h Å¿o Å¿trongly aÅ¿Å¿aulteth thee that it carrieth thee captiue to the Law of Å¿inne, and neuer ceaÅ¿eth vntill that it hath brought thee to be a moÅ¿t miÅ¿erable creature.
QueÅ¿t. Doe you think, that you are bound to doe, as they did promiÅ¿e for you?

AnÅ¿w. Yes verily, and by Gods helpe, Å¿o J will. And I heartily thanke our heauenly father, that hath called mee to this Å¿tate of Å¿aluation through IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t our Sauiour, and I pray God to giue mee his grace, that I may continue in the Å¿ame vnto my liues end.

Explan. This AnÅ¿wer is a manifold cord binding the baptiÅ¿ed vnto theÅ¿e three duties. FirÅ¿t, an acknowledgement of obligation to performe in our owne perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oeuer our Sureties haue vndertaken in our name. The inÅ¿oluble Å¿trength of this bond is euident out of reaÅ¿on and common practiÅ¿e. The rule of Law is, Quod quis per alium facit, per Å¿e facere videtur. What a man doth by another, hee is in law taken to doe it by himÅ¿elfe. If I depute a man to
Å¿eale a bond for mee, his act bindeth me as Å¿ure, as if I had performed it immediately by my Å¿elfe. An oath taken by a Proctor in animam Domini, lyeth vpon the Å¿oule of him that authorized the taker.

Ob. But an infant cannot make any deputation, nor can at all binde himÅ¿elfe, being not of iudgement and diÅ¿cretion Å¿o to doe, and therefore it Å¿eemes wee are free, from whatÅ¿oeuer was vndertaken by others for vs at our BaptiÅ¿me.

Sol WhoÅ¿oeuer hath capacity of being baptized, muÅ¿t needs haue withall a ioynt ability to vndergoe the couenants of BaptiÅ¿me, the duty doth inÅ¿eparably accompany the benefit. The Å¿tipulation of others for an Infant, where it is to his benefit, bindeth not onely in the gifts, but in the annexed duties. Nor doth the Obligation of obedience binde the baptized, meerely by vertue of the promiÅ¿e made by the God-fathers: though there were no Å¿uch promiÅ¿e made by others for the childe, nor expreÅ¿sly by the party baptized (in caÅ¿e hee Å¿hould then bee of age) yet this holdeth ex natura rei, as an inÅ¿eparable condition accompanying the Sacrament of baptiÅ¿me: inaÅ¿much as all baptizing is into the Å¿imilitude of ChriÅ¿ts death,

WhoÅ¿oeuer therefore, whether man or childe hath ability to be baptized, muÅ¿t needes withall bee of capacity to vndergoe the couenants of BaptiÅ¿me. All which I haue here inÅ¿erted, as probable, not as neceÅ¿Å¿arily inforcing, Jerom. EpiÅ¿t. 41. partis. 1. Some, I knowe, are offended hereat, and doe refuÅ¿e to conforme

Moreouer, how can the miniÅ¿ter giue the Lords body to him, that is appointed by the Lord to be giuen ouer to Satan; for as it was with the inceÅ¿tuous perÅ¿on againÅ¿t the Corinthians,1 Cor. 5.5. Å¿o is it with euery notorious Å¿candalous liuer, he is, vntill repentance to bee put from the communion of Gods people. Thus we Å¿ee what a maze or labyrinth Å¿in doth bring men into; in danger they are by comming, and in danger by not comming to the Lords Table.
QueÅ¿t. 139. What may a man doe then in this caÅ¿e?

AnÅ¿w. He muÅ¿t humbly Å¿ue vnto God for the pardon of all his Å¿ins, to Å¿trike his hard heart, that he may melt into teares for them, and conÅ¿tantly cleaue to his commandements; and if there be any diÅ¿Å¿ention, he muÅ¿t goe, and be reconciled to his brother.

Explan. So gracious is our good God, as that when wee are brought into deÅ¿perate Å¿traights, and wildred Å¿o by Å¿inne, as that we know not which way to get out, hee holdeth forth the thread of his mercy, by the helpe of which wee may come into the right way againe. Like vnto AhaÅ¿hueroÅ¿h his Å¿cepter Å¿tretched out towards his beloued HeÅ¿ter, when Å¿hee was intangled with danger: euen Å¿o is the Lords Scepter euer held out vnto vs, that in the name of his Sonne we may come vnto him, though wee be moÅ¿t wretched Å¿inners. I anÅ¿wer, was not the Publican likewiÅ¿e in his Å¿innes? and yet hee prayed, and was heard and iuÅ¿tified, and did not the Thiefe vpon the CroÅ¿Å¿e likewiÅ¿e? So that wicked men praying

QueÅ¿t. 140. What ought a man to doe at the Lords Supper?

AnÅ¿w. FirÅ¿t, the Lords giuing of his Sonne IeÅ¿us to death for vs, Å¿et forth by the MiniÅ¿ters taking of the bread and wine, breaking and powring out, and offering it to vs all. Secondly, our neare vnion vnto ChriÅ¿t, and how we haue all our Å¿pirituall foode from him, Å¿et forth by our taking, eating, and inward digeÅ¿ting the bread and wine that becommeth nouriÅ¿hment vnto vs. Thirdly, the neare vnion that God hath made by ChriÅ¿t betwixt all the faithfull, Å¿et forth by the Å¿ame bread being made of many graines of corne, and by the Å¿ame wine being made of many grapes.

Expl. I Å¿hall not need largely here to intreat of theÅ¿e meditations which hath been done already; onely the Communicant that commeth to the Lords Table is to bee aduert â¢ Å¿ed, that by no meanes he bee there an idle beholder of things done, but a profitable ponderer of all circumÅ¿tances, to Å¿tirre him vp to greateÅ¿t thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e vnto God for Å¿o great benefits. In which, that hee may bee holpen, let him firÅ¿t herein conÅ¿ider Gods admirable loue, in giuing his Sonne to death for his Å¿innes, his holy body to be broken, and his pure bloud to be Å¿hed: for without Gods giuing of his Sonne to the curÅ¿ed death of the CroÅ¿Å¿e, all the power of the Scribes, PhariÅ¿ees and high PrieÅ¿ts was not able to doe it. Wherefore he Å¿aith, I lay downe my life for my Å¿heepe, and no man taketh it from me, but J lay it downe of my Å¿elfe. Euen as if a man being condemned to die, another moÅ¿t louing friend Å¿hould lay downe his life, and Å¿uffer for him; Oh how thankfully were this loue to
be remembred, and with what praiÅ¿es to bee celebrated, as being vnmatchable by any loue that euer hath been Å¿eene amongÅ¿t men: for a deare friend, there hath been in many ages one amongÅ¿t many Kingdoms of the Latines, one amongÅ¿t many of the Grecians, that haue offered to die for their friends; but for their enemies neuer any. Lord, therefore Å¿hould the Å¿oule of euery ChriÅ¿tian Å¿ay, I offer againe vnto thee mine own Å¿elf, Å¿oule & body to Å¿erue thee, and my old nature to be killed and Å¿laine with al the concupiÅ¿cences thereof, though neuer Å¿o deare vnto me, for thou haÅ¿t offered thy deare Å¿onne for mee, and vnto me without any deÅ¿ert of mine, and for this cauÅ¿e art moÅ¿t worthy of all honour, and thankÅ¿giuing.

Secondly, let the Communicant conÅ¿ider of Gods admirable loue in vniting him Å¿o neare vnto his Sonne, and through his Å¿onne vnto himÅ¿elfe, and in feeding him from heauen with Å¿uch comforts, without which his Å¿oule muÅ¿t needs bee hungerÅ¿tarued, and periÅ¿h.

Iohn 17.21. This was ChriÅ¿ts prayer vnto the Father, that we might be one with him, that they may all be one, as thou, O Father art in me, and I in thee, that they may be alÅ¿o one in vs: and this did he my Å¿tically in this Sacrament Å¿hadow out vnto vs. When Dauid was offered the Kings Daughter, and to be the Kings Sonne in Law, Who am I, Å¿aid he, that I Å¿hould be Sonne in Law to a King? and, who am I, Å¿hould the Communicant Å¿ay, that I Å¿hould bee made one with the King of Heauen? MoÅ¿t vnÅ¿peakable (O Lord) is thy loue towards me, that thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t haue Å¿uch reÅ¿pect to Å¿o poore a worme, to raiÅ¿e me out of the duÅ¿t, to Å¿it with thy ChriÅ¿t,Rom. 8.1 â¢ . of Å¿o great dignity, to be Å¿o ioyned vnto him, that I Å¿hould be made coheire with him of the heauenly Kingdome? How can I doe leÅ¿Å¿e then put away all baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e of mind, whereby I cleaue to the world and the fleÅ¿h, and bee like minded to my deare Sauiour (to whom I am ioyned in fellowÅ¿hip, though moÅ¿t vnworthy) being holy as he is holy.

It is alÅ¿o to bee conÅ¿idered, how our Å¿oules are fed heere euen as the IÅ¿raelites with Manna from heauen, in the wilderneÅ¿Å¿e, where they muÅ¿t otherwiÅ¿e haue periÅ¿hed: and as Dauid
flying from Saul, by Abimelech, with the hazard of his owne life; Å¿o God Å¿pared not his Å¿onne, but gaue him, as bread from heauen vnto vs, without which wee muÅ¿t needs haue periÅ¿hed for euer, and in our greateÅ¿t need, that wee might haue Å¿trength to flie away from the danger of Satan inraged againÅ¿t vs, he Å¿pared not, though with the hazard of his life to giue vs the true Shew-bread. Oh how Å¿hould my heart be affected towards thee, O Lord, therefore, and reÅ¿olued to abide alwaies with thee, vowing with Dauid to Abiathar, Hee that Å¿eeketh my life, Å¿hall Å¿eeke thy life alÅ¿o, thoÅ¿e that are thy enemies Å¿hall be mine, and as if they hated me.

Thirdly, let the Communicant conÅ¿ider of the neere vnion that the Lord hath made by ChriÅ¿t betwixt all his Saints, into the which hee is alÅ¿o receiued, that faithfully partaketh of the Lords Supper: which Å¿hould effectually Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e all exorbitant affections, and worke an holy loue in him, as towards members of the Å¿ame body.
QueÅ¿t. 142. What is to be done after the receiuing?

AnÅ¿w. We muÅ¿t meditate of the Couenant of new obedience with the Lord renewed by this Sacrament, that we may be more carefull to performe this obedience, and to flee Å¿inne and vice all the dayes of our life.

Explan. The receiuing of the Lords Supper is not a tranÅ¿ient holy duty, as it is by moÅ¿t men vÅ¿ed (who put Å¿ome holineÅ¿Å¿e vpon them for the time, afterwards returning as the dogge to the vomit, and as the Å¿wine to the wallowing in the mire) but it is a Å¿ealing of couenants betwixt God and his people, and the grace of God for the pardon of all our Å¿innes; and our dutifulneÅ¿Å¿e to God, in forÅ¿aking all our old Å¿innes, and liuing according to his holy lawes: For as God doth hereby giue himÅ¿elfe vnto vs to become our God, and gracious Father; Å¿o we giue our Å¿elues vnto God, to become his people, and obedient children.

There be theÅ¿e two parties in all couenants, otherwiÅ¿e they cannot Å¿tand, Å¿omething aÅ¿Å¿ured and giuen, and Å¿omething taken and receiued therefore: So betwixt Princes and Subiects; the Prince giueth and aÅ¿Å¿ureth his care in ruling, and prouiding well for the good of the Subiect, hee receiueth tribute,
cuÅ¿tome and obedience: Å¿o betwixt maÅ¿ters and Å¿eruants, betwixt Å¿ellers and buyers, lenders and borrowers.

In like manner in this Couenant God for his part aÅ¿Å¿ureth, and giueth himÅ¿elfe to be our gracious God, forgiuing all our treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es, and on our part, he muÅ¿t receiue tribute, Å¿ubiection and obedience, otherwiÅ¿e the bond is forfeit, and if it hath bin Å¿o once, twiÅ¿e, or often, and the forfeit hath not yet been taken, take heed of the next time, for if thou Å¿till remaine vnreformed, not better keeping couenants, hauing renewed them Å¿o many times, there is no hope for thee to bee dealt withall, but as with a deÅ¿perate perÅ¿on, that thou Å¿houldÅ¿t Å¿uddenly be deliuered to Å¿ome infernall Å¿pirit, the Taylor, and Å¿o be impriÅ¿oned in Hell, whence thou canÅ¿t neuer come out againe.

If thou haÅ¿t therefore neglected to pay God the duties of praiÅ¿e and prayer, of obedience, and performance of holy duties, both publike and priuate, now bee negligent no longer, but be rather officious, redeeming the time with double diligence; if thou haÅ¿t loued and liued in Å¿inne, and diÅ¿obedience, keepe couenants by feare of offending any more hereafter, and if thou haÅ¿t no way anÅ¿wered that loue, which the Lord tieth thee vnto towards thy neighbour for his owne Å¿ake, but haÅ¿t hated Å¿uch as haue Å¿hewed any enmity againÅ¿t thee; for offences haÅ¿t been vnaduiÅ¿edly prouoked, and through an immoderate loue of thy Å¿elfe, and of the world, haÅ¿t denied food vnto the hungry, and haÅ¿t Å¿ought to beguile thy neighbour; learne of ChriÅ¿t to be meeke and gentle, in holineÅ¿Å¿e, follow Paul as he followeth ChriÅ¿t, and for bounty, imitate Zacheus conuerted, giuing liberally to the poore, and Å¿atisfying where thou haÅ¿t done wrong to any man: for thus, and thus onely mayÅ¿t thou haue comfort of the Lords Supper, and Å¿halt in his good time Å¿it downe in the Kingdome of Heauen, and be feaÅ¿ted with Abraham, IÅ¿aak, and Iacob, for euer and euer.

div.p: FOraÅ¿much as the holy Scriptures are the ground and foundation of all diuine Teaching; and it auayleth not a little for Å¿etting men in the Trueth, to vnderÅ¿tand rightly both which bee the Bookes of holy Scripture, and how wee may bee aÅ¿Å¿ured, that they are the Word of God, and by whom, and how this Word is to be preached, and heard, for our further building vp in grace, I haue thought it expedient here to annexe theÅ¿e Å¿hort QueÅ¿tions and AnÅ¿weres following.
QueÅ¿t. 143. What is the Word of God?
AnÅ¿w. WhatÅ¿oeuer is contained in the books of the old and new Testament, and not any other bookes or writings whatÅ¿oeuer.
QueÅ¿t. 144. How many, and which are theÅ¿e Bookes?

The Books of Canonicall Scripture.AnÅ¿w. The Bookes of the Olde Testament are twentie and Å¿eauen, GeneÅ¿is, Exodus, Leuiticus, Numbers, Deuteronomie, IoÅ¿ua, Iudges, Ruth, the first and Å¿econd of Samuel, the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd of the Kings, the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd of the Chronicles, Ezra, Nehemiah, EÅ¿ter, Iob, PÅ¿almes, Prouerbs, EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tes, Song of Songs, EÅ¿ay, Ieremiah, with his Lamentation, Ezechiel, Daniel, and the Booke of the twelue Å¿mall Prophets. The Bookes of the New Testament are twentie and Å¿ixe, Matthew, Marke, Luke, and Iohn, the Actes of the ApoÅ¿tles, the EpiÅ¿tle of Paul to the Romanes, the firÅ¿t and
Å¿econd to the Corinthians, to the Galathians, EpheÅ¿ians, Philippians, ColloÅ¿sians, the first and Å¿econd to the TheÅ¿Å¿alonians, the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd to Timothie, to Titus, to the Hebrewes, the EpiÅ¿tle of Iames, the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd of Peter, the firÅ¿t, Å¿econd, and third of Iohn, the EpiÅ¿tle of Iude, and the Reuelation of Iohn.
QueÅ¿t. 145. Are not the other Books called Apocryphall, part of the Word of God alÅ¿o, as EÅ¿dras, Tobit, Iudeth, &c.
AnÅ¿w. They are not bookes properly called Canonicall but are annexed to the word, as being full of good inÅ¿tructions and hiÅ¿tories, declaring Gods wonderfull prouidence ouer his people IÅ¿rael.
Explan. Diuers haue beene and are the errours of men about Gods Word, Å¿ome denying diuers parts of the Old and New TeÅ¿tament to bee his Word: and Å¿ome Canonizing other writings alÅ¿o.

Concerning the firÅ¿t, Å¿ome deteÅ¿table Heretiques haue receiued none for the word of God, but the fine Bookes of MoÅ¿es as the Sadduces; Å¿ome none but the New TeÅ¿tament, as the Manich â¢ es, and Marcion: Å¿ome haue reiected the Booke of PÅ¿almes, as the Nicholaitans, and AnabaptiÅ¿ts: Å¿ome the booke of Iob, as Å¿ome Rabbins; and Å¿ome Daniel as Porphyrius: Å¿ome haue reiected the GoÅ¿pel of Luke, as Cerdon, Å¿ome all but Marke, as Cerinthus; Å¿ome the GoÅ¿pel of Iohn, as the Alog â¢ ; Å¿ome all Pauls works, as the Ebionites, &c.

Concerning the Å¿econd, Å¿ome haue made the Apocryphall Books of equall authoritie with the fore recited Scriptures, as the PapiÅ¿ts, and others haue more boldly long Å¿ince obtruded for Canonical, the fatherleÅ¿Å¿e brood of other books vnto theÅ¿e, as the third and fourth of Eldras, and Appendix of Iob, a Preface to the Lamentation, the third and fourth of the Macchabees, a Booke called
ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , the Booke of Enoch, the GoÅ¿pel of Thomas and of Matthias, the acts of Peter. And in the yeare 1120 a certaine new GoÅ¿pell, called Euangelium aeternum, the eternall GoÅ¿pell, was found out, being full of blaÅ¿phemies:
but all theÅ¿e and the like are damnable preÅ¿umptions, plainly forbidden by the Lord, Å¿aying;Deut 4.2. Ye Å¿hal not put ought vnto the word that I command you, neither Å¿hall ye take ought there-from: and grieuouÅ¿ly threatned,Reu. 22.18 19. If any man Å¿hall adde vnto theÅ¿e things, God Å¿hall adde vnto him the plagues that are written in this Booke; and if any man Å¿hall diminiÅ¿h any thing, God Å¿hall take away his part out of the Booke of life.
Now that the Books firÅ¿t aboue named are all Canonicall Scriptures, and part of the word of God,EpiÅ¿t. Tom. 3. hath been acknowledged in all ages, by the ChriÅ¿tian Church

Ierome writing to Paulinus of the Å¿tudy of the holy Scriptures, doth both reckon vp all theÅ¿e bookes in particular, and adioyneth to euery one of them a Å¿euerall pithy commendation. And vnto Leta he preÅ¿cribeth an order of reading them with moÅ¿t Å¿afetie and profit.

As for the other Bookes,EpiÅ¿t. Tom. 1. which our Church adioyneth to the volume of the inÅ¿pired Scriptures, they are both entertained, and in part publikely read in our Churches, not as authentike Principles, whereon to ground any doctrine, but as wholeÅ¿ome precepts of moralitie, and declarations of the eÅ¿tate of the Church in thoÅ¿e times, very profitable for deuotion, and heauenly meditation.
Quest. 146. What Å¿peciall proofe is there, making manifeÅ¿t that thoÅ¿e Bookes of Scripture are the word of God?

AnÅ¿w. The antiquity of thoÅ¿e books, Å¿ome of them being before all other bookes Å¿undry times oppugned, and Å¿ought to be burnt vp by perÅ¿ecutors, and yet wonderfully preÅ¿erued, and by miracles from heauen confirmed, is a manifest proofe, that they came from heauen, and are not of mans inuention.

That the
â¢ oly Scriptures are Gods word. Explan. AmongÅ¿t all arguments there is none of that force in the conÅ¿cience of man; that this is of being taken from the diuinitie of the holy Scriptures. For let it appeare that they are of God, and what heart dares doe any other but yeeld vnto them? Now, that they are of God, may bee plainely prooued by Å¿undry reaÅ¿ons.

FirÅ¿t, by their Antiquitie; for the firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t ancient writings in the world concerning Religion, muÅ¿t needs be Gods, but theÅ¿e are the firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t ancient; therefore muÅ¿t needs be Gods.

1. That the moÅ¿t ancient are Gods Scriptures, is plaine; becauÅ¿e otherwiÅ¿e either Å¿ome other InÅ¿tructor muÅ¿t haue beene before God: or elÅ¿e God, the Ruler of the whole world, muÅ¿t haue beene without any thing recorded, whereby the world ought to be ruled, till that man had inuented Å¿omething to gouerne man by; both which are moÅ¿t abÅ¿urd.

That the holy Scriptures are moÅ¿t ancient, appeareth by the moÅ¿t ancient humane writers. Orpheus, the firÅ¿t of all, writeth of the two Tables deliuered to MoÅ¿es. Whence he Å¿aith, that he learned what he knew of God. Linus wrote of the Tower of Babylon deÅ¿cribed by MoÅ¿es, &c. making plaine heereby that the Bookes of MoÅ¿es were long before any of their writings, and Å¿o the moÅ¿t ancient in the world. Hence it is that Tacianus affirmeth that it appeareth out of BeroÅ¿us a Caldee Writer,Tatiani Oratio aduerÅ¿us gentes, MoÅ¿es fuit Baccho antiquior & plurimis diis gentium Clem. Alexandr. out of the writings of the Phoenicians and Annales of the Egyptians, that MoÅ¿es wrote long before Orpheus, Linus, Amphyon, Homer, or the moÅ¿t ancient Ethnickes. Now the Bookes of MoÅ¿es are in effect the whole Scriptures, all that followeth tending onely to the further explanation heereof. Wherefore the Scriptures are moÅ¿t auncient, and conÅ¿equently the vndoubted word of God.

2. This is further prooued by the preÅ¿eruation of the Scriptures in all ages, other ancient Bookes being periÅ¿hed either in part or in whole, but the holy Scriptures, though more oppugned then any by perÅ¿ecutors, who haue Å¿ought to blot out the memory of them, yet are wholly preÅ¿erued without diminution or corruption of any part of them. Had they beene of man, certainly it would haue happened vnto them as vnto many other humane writings, which are moÅ¿t ancient: which, if they haue not periÅ¿hed, yet they haue been falÅ¿ified: yea, one complaineth, that hee himÅ¿elfe yet
liuing to Å¿ee it, Fratribus rogantibus, vt Å¿criberem EpiÅ¿tolas, Å¿cripÅ¿i, has Apostoli, Diaboli Zizanijs alia eximentes, alia ad â¢ icientes, DionyÅ¿ius Areo â¢ pag. repleuerunt. The Brethren requeÅ¿ting I wrote EpiÅ¿tles, theÅ¿e the ApoÅ¿tles of the Deuill haue filled with tares, adding Å¿ome things, and taking away otherÅ¿ome. Now the holy Scriptures haue been Å¿ingularly preÅ¿erued heerein, in the hands of the Iewes, who haue miÅ¿liked Å¿ome things, and forbidden them to be read, as Daniel, becauÅ¿e he Å¿peaketh Å¿o plainly of the MeÅ¿siah: in the hands of the heathen, as when at the requeÅ¿t of Ptolomee they were tranÅ¿lated by the Septuagint, and in the hands of Heretikes, who haue corrupted Fathers and Councels, yet neuer durÅ¿t, but haue beene reÅ¿trained from heauen, from corrupting the Scriptures.

3. This is further proued by the miracles which haue been wrought to confirme the Scriptures to be of God, the Author of all true miracles: of this Å¿ort are the miracles wought by MoÅ¿es, by the Prophets, by ChriÅ¿t, and by his DiÅ¿ciples. For all theÅ¿e miracles doe plainly teÅ¿tifie of them, that they were Å¿ent of God; and if they were of God, then the word by them Å¿et forth is the word of God.

4. The Å¿ame is proued by the propheÅ¿ies contained in the Scriptures, Å¿ome being of things to come to paÅ¿Å¿e many hundreds of yeares after, as that the Å¿eed of the woman Å¿hould breake the Å¿erpents head, that Abrahams poÅ¿terity Å¿hould be numberleÅ¿Å¿e, that they Å¿hould be Å¿trangers 400. yeares, that JoÅ¿iah Å¿hould burne the bones of Baals PrieÅ¿ts where Ieroboam did Å¿acrifice, that the people of IÅ¿rael Å¿hould be in captiuity 70. yeares, that Cyrus expreÅ¿Å¿ely forenamed, Å¿hould giue them leaue to returne and diuerÅ¿ly honour them, &c. From hence we may reaÅ¿on thus: ThoÅ¿e Scriptures which in their reuelations exceed all the vnderÅ¿tanding of all creatures, are vndoubtedly his who is aboue all creatures, that is Gods: but Å¿uch are the holy Scriptures, as appeareth by theÅ¿e & the like PropheÅ¿ies. Ergo, &c. for no created vnderÅ¿tanding can of it Å¿elfe reach to things to come, to Å¿ay certainly thus it Å¿hal be: Å¿ome may coniecture, or being appointed as inÅ¿truments of execution may declare what themÅ¿elues Å¿hall performe, as
the Deuill did to Saul, but God onely hath made it Å¿o proper to himÅ¿elfe to foretell independently, abÅ¿olutely, and infallibly what Å¿hall come afterwards, as that it may well be Å¿aid, Let them tell what Å¿hall come, let them doe good or euill, and Å¿ay that they be Gods.

5. The Å¿ame is further proued by the Argument handled in the Scriptures, which is altogether graue & holy, tending to the Å¿etting forth of all vertue, and againÅ¿t all vice, wheras (as IuÅ¿tine Martyr hath obÅ¿erued) the writers of the Heathen gods and religion,IuÅ¿tin Martyr. were either ridiculous Poets, which deriue the beginning of all from the waters, & handle the quarrels, and filthy loues of the gods: or PhyloÅ¿ophers more ridiculous: for that the very chiefe of them were vncertaine of the beginning of things. Now Å¿uch as the writing is, Å¿uch muÅ¿t needs be the Author from whom it firÅ¿t commeth; true it is, that he which is vnholy may write things holy & good, but then they come not from him, but firÅ¿t from Å¿ome other fountaine: therefore the moÅ¿t holy, who is God, muÅ¿t needs be the Author of the holy Scriptures.

6. This is proued by the teÅ¿timony of Heathen men themÅ¿elues. The Law of MoÅ¿es againÅ¿t Images, Numa Pompilius the chiefe religious Emperour amongÅ¿t the heathen Romans approued of. Numenius a Pythagorean; PhyloÅ¿opher Å¿aith of Plato, that hee was none other but MoÅ¿es Å¿peaking in the Atticke tongue.EuÅ¿eb. de prepar. Euang. The Oracle of Apollo, confeÅ¿Å¿ed, that the ChriÅ¿tians onely had the truth, and acknowledged the true God, Å¿aith EuÅ¿ebius. Tribellius Pollio writing of MoÅ¿es, Å¿aith, that hee was the only man familiar with God. Cornelius Tacitus confeÅ¿Å¿eth the truth of that HiÅ¿tory in Exodus, telling how Pharaoh after many plagues, let the children of IÅ¿rael goe, though hee thruÅ¿t in Å¿ome abÅ¿urd fabulous lyes concerning the Iewes. Procopius teÅ¿tifieth of IoÅ¿hua, that for feare of him the Phoenicians left their country. Linus and Homer write of the Creation of the world in Å¿ixe dayes. Ouid of the generall deluge, as alÅ¿o of the Gyants rearing of mountaines vp to heauen, which is an alluÅ¿ion to the Tower of Babell. Abidenus, Sybilla and Hestiaeus of the long liues of the Ancients. Epolemus
of Abraham, and how he fought for Lot. Plato confeÅ¿Å¿eth, that he learned the moÅ¿t excellent precepts of wiÅ¿dom of the barbarous, (meaning MoÅ¿es and the Prophets.) Now whence commeth this conÅ¿ent of men of contrary minds to the truth of the Scriptures? Verily, from Gods prouidence, that no man might deny that, which by the light of nature is acknowledged of naturall man, viz the truth and Diuinitie of the Scriptures.

7. The Å¿ame is proued by the Å¿ingle drift of the Scriptures, which is only, to giue all glory to God, nothing to man, Å¿eeing that the faults of the beÅ¿t are ingenuouÅ¿ly and without flattery Å¿et downe; neither is any mans fauour affected or Å¿ought for in any of theÅ¿e books, which cannot be Å¿aid of any humane writings.

8. The Å¿ame is proued by the conÅ¿ent of all the books of holy Scripture, though written by diuers men at Å¿undry times. Neuer was the like to be found touching mens writings, but euen the Å¿ame Author hath been oftentimes noted to differ from himÅ¿elfe. Wherefore the Writers of the holy Scriptures were vndoubtedly guided by one Å¿pirit of truth, and what they wrote came from this Å¿pirit which is God. If any differences Å¿eeme to be in theÅ¿e holy writings, this is, through the weakneÅ¿Å¿e of our conceit and miÅ¿vnderÅ¿tanding, and not indeed.

QueÅ¿t. 147. Hauing this Word of God written, is it not Å¿ufficient for our Å¿aluation without any other helpe, euen as to haue a Booke of Statutes, Å¿ufficeth to be kept from the danger of the Law, to thoÅ¿e that will?

Explan. Many there be who acknowledge the Scriptures to be Gods word; but doe not Å¿o much regard the preaching
of this word, proÅ¿uming vpon their owne ability, to make a good vÅ¿e of it in priuat by reading, for their edification, and Å¿aluation. And Å¿ome colour of reaÅ¿on there is alÅ¿o for this, Å¿eeing that the word Å¿erueth to acquaint vs with the wil and law of God, as a Å¿tatute booke, with the Lawes of the land; and knowing theÅ¿e Lawes, if we will not obey, all preaching cannot bring vs to obedience, or doe vs more good. But this is a deceitfull colour. FirÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e a Statute book is not like vnto Gods booke, that being humane, and the penalty Å¿enÅ¿ible, this diuine and Å¿pirituall; and not vnderÅ¿tood by a naturall man: Å¿o that a man may read much here, but remain Å¿till as deÅ¿titute of vnderÅ¿tanding,Actes 8. as the Eunuch who asked, How can I vnderÅ¿tand without an Interpreter?
Secondly, becauÅ¿e preaching is the meane by which God hath wrought in all ages, and will principally and moÅ¿t powerfully worke by this ordinarily for our Å¿aluation.

1. Cor. 1.18. 1 Pet. 2, 2. Thirdly, becauÅ¿e no man can receiue the word to his comfort, vnleÅ¿Å¿e he reuerence and eÅ¿teeme of the preaching therof, Å¿eeing that the word it Å¿elfe doth Å¿o highly commend and vrge to attend to preaching.

Fourthly, becauÅ¿e the Lord, who onely can giue light by his word, doth direct Å¿uch as be in darknes, to the Preachers of his word, Saul to Ananias, Cornelius to Peter, the Eunuch to Philip &c. refuÅ¿ing otherwiÅ¿e to giue them any light.

LaÅ¿tly, becauÅ¿e men are naturally dull and backward to that which is good, when they know it, Å¿o that reading only they are Å¿till frozen in their Å¿ins: it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, that by the exhortation of preaching they Å¿hould bee Å¿tirred vp, and by the zeale and heat of others bee warmed and become agile and chearefull to doe accordingly.

In all things wee Å¿ay for comfort, Two are better then one: and why Å¿hould it not be Å¿o in this alÅ¿o? A man reading alone is forgetfull, and letteth it flip Å¿oone out of his mind which he readeth: a faithfull MiniÅ¿ter of Gods word preacheth vnto him, and bringeth continually to his remembrance; hee is like a Å¿ticke lying by a firebrand ready to goe out; the MiniÅ¿ter Å¿tirres vp the fire, and layes the Å¿tickes together, he
hath bread by him, but is feeble, becauÅ¿e he cannot breake it in pieces to eate Å¿ome of it, the MiniÅ¿ter breakes it vnto him for his comfort.

I conclude therefore, that it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to exerciÅ¿e the hearing of this Word preached, beÅ¿ides the priuate reading thereof, and hee that hauing the meanes, contemneth them, wandreth Å¿till in Å¿inne and blindneÅ¿Å¿e.
QueÅ¿t. 148. What is the preaching of the Word of God?

Nehem. 8.9. Explan. Some there be, that moue as much trouble about preaching, as others that deny the neceÅ¿sity hereof, and content themÅ¿elues onely with reading: Å¿ome affirming the bare reading of the Scriptures to be preaching; Å¿ome talking hereof one neighbour to another, and Å¿ome the reading of Homilies or Sermons. But the preaching of the word to Å¿peak properly is more then all theÅ¿e, as may appeare both by the practiÅ¿e in the dayes of Nehemiah, when it is Å¿aid, that the PrieÅ¿t Å¿tood vpon a place higher then the people, and read the Law of God plainely, and expounding the Å¿ence gaue the vnderÅ¿tanding of the Scriptures. Men and brethren if there be in you any word of exhortation vnto the people, Å¿peake. From hence ariÅ¿eth plainelie this deÅ¿cription of Preaching, to be an expounding, &c. as in the AnÅ¿were.

Now for reading the Scriptures (though in a large Å¿enÅ¿e it be a kind of preaching, becauÅ¿e that the truth is hereby Å¿et forth, and the GoÅ¿pell, and meanes of Å¿aluation made known to him that readeth, or heareth it read; yet it is properly no more preaching, then reading is an Oration; neither is hee that doth thus any more a Preacher, then Å¿uch an one, an Oratour. For vnleÅ¿Å¿e they Å¿triue to make their reading Å¿uch a preaching, they queÅ¿tion about nothing, if to make it Å¿uch a preaching they Å¿triue againÅ¿t the Å¿treame, the whole current of examples recorded in the Word, being againÅ¿t them: yea, that Å¿peciall place, which they think a moÅ¿t Å¿ure ground for them. MoÅ¿es hath of old Å¿uch as preach him, when he is read in their Synagogues euery Sabbath day, Acts 15.26. doth plainely rebuke their negligence, Å¿eeing that it may well be hence gathered, that at all times vpon the Sabbath, when the PrieÅ¿ts read MoÅ¿es, they expounded and gaue light vnto the people by teaching, as in Nehemiahs daies. Much more might bee Å¿aid for the confute of Å¿uch groÅ¿Å¿e opinions; but becauÅ¿e I propounded to bee briefe in all things, thus much Å¿hall Å¿uffice briefly for this.

Let vs all lay aÅ¿ide partiality, whereby wee are carried to fauour our Å¿elues, and Å¿eeke our owne eaÅ¿e, and this corrupt fountaine of Å¿uch troubled opinions being dammed vp, I doubt not but wee Å¿hall with one conÅ¿ent endeauour to preach in another manner, then by reading and familiar talking, applying our Å¿elues to the right vnderÅ¿tanding of the Scriptures, that we may giue the right Å¿enÅ¿e, after the Å¿enÅ¿e, find out Å¿ound and profitable doctrines, Å¿trengthened with good reaÅ¿on, conuincing the iudgement, and after the doctrines, frame Å¿ome forcible exhortations, to bring and bow the affections to the light Å¿et vp in the vnderÅ¿tanding, that Gods people may haue more grace, and his holy name more glorie.

Iohn. 4.10. Prayer is as Iacobsâª Ladder Å¿et vp to heauen, by which the Å¿oule aÅ¿cendeth, and fetcheth downe Gods bleÅ¿sing, it is the knocking, Å¿eeking, and asking that euer preuaileth, it obtaineth water of life, though there bee nothing to draw it with, as ChriÅ¿t told the Woman of Samaria, Å¿aying; If thou hadÅ¿t asked, I would haue giuen thee of the water of life. For diligence in hearing, where this preparation is made, that will certainely follow; for a man Å¿hall not neede to bid him that is hungry and in want, to haÅ¿ten to a feaÅ¿t, or to come Å¿o often as hee may, or to apply himÅ¿elfe to feeding, when hee commeth there: for hee commeth with Å¿uch a Å¿tomacke, as that hee will Å¿urely doe Å¿o: In like manner, hee that commeth rightly prepared to heare the Word of GOD, will neglect no time when hee may come, nor loÅ¿e his part of that Å¿pirituall food when he is there.

Hee doth reuerence the Ordinance of GOD, being rightly compoÅ¿ed in geÅ¿ture, but aboue all, inwardly affected in heart: for he trembleth at the word, he is pricked inwardly at the preaching,EÅ¿ay 66.2. div.p:

And through a daily cuÅ¿tom of Å¿inning, it is Å¿o come to paÅ¿Å¿e, as that we are inÅ¿enÅ¿ible and without feeling of the heauy weight & burthen of Å¿inne, it preÅ¿Å¿eth not our hearts, it doth not inwardly grieue vs, we cannot Å¿acrifice broken hearts and contrite Å¿pirits vnto thee, therefore miÅ¿erable creatures that we are, who Å¿hall deliuer vs from the body of this death? Good Father do thou therefore deliuer vs, through thy al-Å¿ufficient grace Å¿anctifie vs, and through thy infinite mercy in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, Å¿aue vs from all our Å¿innes. div.head: A Prayer for the Sabbath, before publike meeting.
div.p:

div.p:
MOÅ¿t gracious God, the fountaine of all goodneÅ¿Å¿e, wee deÅ¿ire with thankfull hearts to acknowledge, that as at all times, Å¿o eÅ¿pecially this day, euen Å¿treames of thy grace haue flowed vnto vs to refreÅ¿h vs, when we were drie.
